resources.string: Physical Activity, Sports and Health Promotion Study Center

The Stabilizer Muscle Tests apk is the result of the research activity of the R+D+i project \"Prevention of Injuries in Physical Activity and Sport\" that emerged in 2018 and is approved by the Scientific Council of the University of Sciences of the Physical Culture and Sport \"Manuel Fajardo\" in 2019.
ABOUT THE STABILIZER MUSCLE TESTS APK
1. Lifestyle and physical activity and sport.\\n2. Physical education, human development and social inclusion.\\n3. Knowledge management on healthy physical condition and life cycle.

Contribute to the generation of knowledge and training of skills that promote efficient and responsible professional performance, in the field of Physical Activity, Sports, Health Promotion and Education.
Promote the management of knowledge about physical activity, sports and health education, anticipating social demand with an inter, multi and transdisciplinary approach.

The apk aims to be a tool that allows the user to be able to evaluate, control and direct the training of resistance to the strength of the stabilizing muscles for Physical Activity and Sports. It provides evaluative criteria and dosage of specific physical exercises for the development of stabilizer muscles.
Before applying the tests, the evaluated must:
1. Carry out the general and special warm-up.
2. In each test, the fullness of the proper posture for the test must be respected (see figure by test) and the established methodology.
3. The test is finished when the subject varies or modifies the appropriate posture for the test (see figure for test) or settles in a different position.
4. A break between tests of 5 to 10 min is established.
5. Block I tests are applied one day first in the order in which they have tests from 1 to 4.
6. On a second day, the Block II tests are applied in the order in which they have tests 1 and 2.
7. On a third day, the Block III tests are applied in the order in which they have tests from 1 to 3.
8. With pain, injury and/or operation, none of the tests are performed.
9. Tests can be applied every 7, 15 or 30 days.

10. If the aim is to determine the test-retest reliability of the tests in a population group, each test must be repeated at least 3 times with rest periods between 5 and 7 days to perform the same test again.

11. The recommended thing is to rest from 24 to 48 hours to apply the tests (Block I rest 24 to 48 hours, Block II rest 24 to 48 hours, Block III rest 24 to 48 hours and I can apply any other type of test).
BLOCK I. Field tests to assess core stability
1. AbdFle (Flexor endurance test) or Trunk flexor endurance test (FE-600)

This test involves the main flexor muscles of the trunk, that is, the rectus abdominis, which is a “global” muscle (McGuill, 2007), and the deep transversus abdominis quadratus lumborum and spinal erector muscles. These muscles stabilize the spine. The angle 600 is obtained by measuring the flexion of the trunk with respect to the floor with a goniometer or tape measure.
Image taken from Mcgill\'s muscular torso endurance test battery
The subject adopts the posture that is observed in the image and will have to maintain it, without modifying it, for as long as possible, which is measured with a stopwatch by the teacher.
« There is a noticeable change in the position of the trunk in deviation of the spine.\n« Roll your shoulders forward.\n« There is an arch in the dorsal back.

Isometric test to fundamentally assess the anterior and posterior muscular resistance of the core. Bliss and Teeple (2005) suggest that the time that the evaluated subjects should endure should be at least 60 seconds.
The subject adopts the posture seen in the image and will have to maintain it, without modifying it, for as long as possible.

« Hay un cambio notable en la posición del tronco en desviación de la columna vertebral.
« Las caderas cambian abajo o hacia arriba en un esfuerzo para mantener equilibrio y estabilidad.
« Lleve los hombros hacia adelante.
« Haya un arco en la espalda dorsal.
3. LsideB (Lateral side endurance tests-Left LsideB) Left lateral bridge (LLB) and RsideB (Lateral side endurance tests-Right RsideB) or Right lateral bridge (RLB)

This test requires activation of the lateral muscles of the core, basically the quadratus lumborum and the internal and external oblique muscles, with low disc compression (Lehman et al., 2005; McGuill, 1998; Axler & McGuill, 1997).
The subject adopts the posture seen in the image and will have to maintain it, without modifying it, for as long as possible.

« Hay un cambio notable en la posición del tronco en desviación de la columna vertebral.
« Las caderas cambian hacia abajo, adelante o hacia atrás en un esfuerzo para mantener equilibrio y estabilidad.
« Lleve el hombro sin apoyo hacia adelante o hacia atrás.
« Haya un arco en la espalda dorsal.
4. Modified Biering-Sorensen test (Biering-Sorensen, 1984) or isometric trunk test (BS-T)
This test activates the main extensor muscles of the trunk, the longissimus and the multifidus, which are part of the “local” stabilizing system (McGuill, 2007), but not the hip muscles.
The subject adopts the posture seen in the image and will have to maintain it, without modifying it, for as long as possible.
Exercise mat, massage table, equipment to do back extensions and stopwatch.
« There is a noticeable change in the position of the trunk in deviation of the spine.\n« Cannot maintain neutral trunk position relative to horizontal.
